column4: SAMPLE SENTENCE
Living close to a lake means we have an ``abundant` supply of water.
Each fall, leaves ``accumulate` in our yard.
Make sure your address is ``accurate` before submitting your online order.
Having 8AM classes means I'm ``accustomed` to getting up early.
When my grandmother died, I ``acquired` her cookbook collection.
The defendant was ``adamant` that he was innocent.
Our house isn't big, but it's ``adequate` for the two of us.
The park is ``adjacent` to the school.

column3: To change something so it serves its purpose better
column4: The bike seat may be two high; you'll probably need to ``adjust` it.

column3: Something that makes it easier to achieve success
column4: His height gives him an ``advantage` in basketball.
My aunt is a major ``advocate` for women's rights.
I had an ``adverse` reaction to my medication and had to stop taking it.
We should ``aggregate` our resources to share them more easily.
The salesperson was very ``aggressive` when trying to get us to buy the television.

column3: To put aside for a specific purpose
column4: The vilage needs to ``allocate` funds for building the new school.
If the ATM is broken, an ``alternative` solution is to stop by the bank.

column3: Someone who is inexperienced or not highly skilled in a particular area
column4: He's an ``amateur` soccer player and is still learning the rules of the game.

column3: Having several potential meanings; unclear and difficult to understand
column4: When I asked the HR manager what my chances were of getting the job, she gave me a very ``ambiguous` reply.
My son is very ``ambitious` and hopes to be a millionaire by the time he's thirty.

column3: To change for the better; to improve
column4: I believe we should ``amend` our country's tax laws.
Our new apartment has ``ample` space for the two of us.
The basketball player is the team's best free thrower, so his missing both shots was an ``anomaly`.
The ``annual` company barbeque takes place every August.

column3: To tease or be hostile towards a person or group
column4: The boy loves to ``antagonize` his little sister by pulling her hair.
After she got grounded, the teenager had a bad ``attitude` for the rest of the day.
Be sure to ``attribute` credit to your sources when writing a research paper.

column3: Based on a whim or random decision
column4: Flipping a coin is an ``arbitrary` way to make a decision.
After you cross the bridge, there's an ``arduous` walk up the hill.
The mother ``assuaged` her child's fear of the dark.
I ``assumed` he was rich because he worked as a lawyer.
She ``augments` her regular salary by babysitting on the weekends.
A ``benefit` of doing homework on Friday is that your weekend will be free.
Our neighbor ``berated` us after we broke his window playing baseball.
The medal was ``bestowed` upon him by the president.

column3: To brag or talk with excessive pride
column4: He always ``boasts` of his talents after he wins a game.

column3: To help raise or increase something
column4: I gave him a pep talk to ``boost` his self-esteem before his speech.
The ``brash` man always asked inappropriate questions.
It will only have a ``brief` meeting, so you'll still have plenty of time for lunch.

column3: Abrupt to the point of rudeness
column4: After being away for so long, I expected more than her ``brusque` greeting.

column3: A harsh, unpleasant mixture of noise
column4: The cuckoo clock shop lets of a ``cacophony` every hour.
I wish they would ``cease` arguing.
Every parent in our district ``censured` the education cuts.

column3: Arranged in order of time or date
column4: Put the historical events in ``chronological` order to make them easier to study.

column3: To make clear; to remove confusion
column4: I didn't understand the instructions, so I asked the teacher to ``clarify` them.
The people on the street eventually ``coalesced` into a group.

column3: To force someone to do something against their will
column4: The young boy was ``coerced` into stealing by his friends.

column3: Being aware or having knowledge of something
column4: Before mountain climbing, you need to be ``cognizant` of the risks.
Water molecules show strong ``cohesion` when they stick together.

column3: To occur at the same time
column4: This year, Thanksgiving ``coincided with my birthday.

column3: To fall down or break down
column4: The old building finally ``collapsed`, leaving nothing but a pile of rubble.

column3: To hit one another with a forceful impact
column4: The two cars ``collided` on the highway.

column3: Dedication to a cause or activity
column4: Joining a school play is a big ``commitment`.  You'll need to practice everyday.

column3: A group of people who live or work together
column4: The Chinese ``community` in my city is hosting a New Year celebration next week.
